In this section, we evaluate the performance of our proposed algorithm. The simulation parameters are as follows:
The number of antennas, M𝑀M, is 100100100.
The number of clients, K𝐾K, is 202020.
The number of local iterations per communication round is 333.
The batch size is 500500500.
We perform image classification on the MNIST data set [18].
We have a very heterogeneous data distribution. Each client only has data from one digit: clients 1 and 2 have digit 0, clients 3 and 4 have digit 1, and so on. Each client has the same number of training samples.
The network architecture is presented in Table I. It has d=12810𝑑12810d=12810 trainable parameters.
The clients keep 0.5%percent0.50.5\% of 𝒙kfullsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘full\bm{x}_{k}^{\text{full}}, i.e., S=⌊0.005​d/2⌋=32𝑆0.005𝑑232S=\lfloor 0.005\,d/2\rfloor=32.
The measurement matrices are constructed as, 𝑨=𝑨r1.01​∥𝑨r∥2𝑨subscript𝑨𝑟1.01subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑨𝑟2\bm{A}=\frac{\bm{A}_{r}}{1.01\left\lVert\bm{A}_{r}\right\rVert_{2}}, where 𝑨rsubscript𝑨𝑟\bm{A}_{r} has 𝒞​𝒩​(0,1)𝒞𝒩01\mathcal{CN}\left(0,1\right) elements and 1.011.011.01 is somewhat arbitrarily chosen to fulfill ∥𝑨∥2<1subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑨21\left\lVert\bm{A}\right\rVert_{2}<1.
The local learning rate is 0.01 and the global learning rate, αtsubscript𝛼𝑡\alpha_{t}, is 13​(10−4​t+1)13superscript104𝑡1\frac{1}{3(10^{-4}t+1)}.
The large scale fading is equispaced (in dB scale) between −4040-40 dB and 00 dB, and the two clients with data of the same digit have equal βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}, i.e., β1=β2=−40subscript𝛽1subscript𝛽240\beta_{1}=\beta_{2}=-40 dB, ……\dots, β19=β20=0subscript𝛽19subscript𝛽200\beta_{19}=\beta_{20}=0 dB.
The length of the transmitted vector is T=10​S=320𝑇10𝑆320T=10S=320.
Finally, we vary the SNR, ρ∈{20,30}𝜌2030\rho\in\{20,30\} dB and the number of pilot symbols, τp∈{K,10​K}={20,200}subscript𝜏p𝐾10𝐾20200\tau_{\text{p}}\in\{K,10K\}=\{20,200\} (for both estimation methods). As mentioned in Section IV, we assume that the whole gradient update fits in a single coherence block. Since T=320𝑇320T=320, and τp=20subscript𝜏p20\tau_{\text{p}}=20 or τp=200subscript𝜏p200\tau_{\text{p}}=200 we need to have coherence intervals which are larger than 340340340 or 520520520 samples. In practice, τc=750subscript𝜏c750\tau_{\text{c}}=750 in an outdoor vehicular scenario [14, Ch. 2]. Since we assume a block fading model, the absolute bandwidth does not affect the system model.
